notesStmt.note: Whitman's note at the top of the page suggests that this manuscript was written in late 1863 or in 1864, following his first year in Washington, D.C.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: "I have had one feeling . . . "
bibl.orgName: The Alice and Rollo G. Silver Collection, Department of Special Collections, Boston University
bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of original manuscript.

revisionDesc.change: corrected title in sourceDesc; moved list of responsible parties to titleStmt; changed "margintop" to "top"

body.p: I have had one feeling steadily aroused & brought forward—that of compassion, (veined with a good deal of indignant bitter) that this huge & most noble myriad of the ranks of America, has been & has is is yet through its regiments, brigades, divisions, corps & armies, quite entirely without commissioned officers, of any rank whatever, in any of the grades (except perhaps a very few of the highest rank,) who appreciate them the the army of the people, & entertain in their souls the true Democracy, out of which only an great army worthy of America & of the modern can be wielded. I have found plenty enough of good-hearted officers, so middling plenty of officers, that the men generally like & respect, but I have the terrible
